MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Cross-Border Economic Co-operation .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if it is his intention to meet a delegation from the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions from Northern Ireland with a view to promoting cross-Border economic co-operation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : In the course of a letter I sent on 11 March to Mr. Colin Lowry, President of the Northern Ireland District Committee of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, I indicated that I should be glad to meet a delegation from the confederation to hear their views on how North-South economic co-operation, to which the Government are strongly committed, can best be developed. A response was recently received from the Harland and Wolff Shipbuilding Sub-Committee of the Northern Ireland District Committee indicating that they are anxious for a meeting. I hope that it will be possible to fix a mutually convenient date for a meeting with a confederation delegation next month.

MainHeading.P: In my letter to Mr. Lowry, I also said that both I and the Minister for Industry and Energy were strongly in favour of closer North-South co-operation where engineering companies in Northern Ireland have the capacity to supply needs in this part of the country. I indicated that in regard to business of interest to Harland and Wolff, it was intended to maintain contacts that had taken place with Mr. Parker, the new chairman and chief executive. This has been done. Appropriate preparations are also in hand, with Departments and agencies concerned, for the proposed meeting with the trade union delegation and, more generally, to provide a basis for co-ordinated implementation of the Government's policy in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : I welcome the Taoiseach's decision to meet this delegation and support the principle of promoting North-South economic co-operation in this way. When the Taoiseach meets this delegation will he be in a position to explain to them why he permitted the ESB principally to set at naught the efforts which I and my Government had made to ensure very beneficial co-operation whereby Harland and Wolff, Irish Shipping and the ESB would combine together to provide the necessary bulk carrier for the new generating station at Moneypoint, County Clare?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : That seems to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Contrary to suggestions in some Northern newspaper reports, clearly based on Opposition briefing that the deal was all but sewn up when the change of Government occurred, very many questions remained unanswered at that time and it was far from clear that any shipping company would be prepared, especially when they had to stand over contract terms, to order a ship in Belfast other than on foot of conditions that would be unacceptable by compelling the ESB to put too many eggs into one basket. In that connection, the best way of summing up the situation as it was when we took over is to read to the House the concluding paragraph of a letter written by my predecessor to Mr. Colin Lowry on 10 December. He said:

The question that must now be decided by the Government here is whether in the light of the facts available it would be justified in pursuing the project and entering into serious inter-governmental negotiations or whether this project should be postponed for some years when hopefully more favourable circumstances will obtain.

I would like you to understand that the Government have been motivated throughout by a wish to place, if possible, a major order with Harland and Wolff. We have pursued this project in good faith and with diligence and have brought it to a point where a decision can be made even if it has to be an unfavourable one.
A gentle let down.

MainHeading.P: Although the meeting between the Belfast unions and the former Taoiseach took place on 5 April 1982, the ESB went to tender on 14 April 1982. As a result of the failure of the former Taoiseach to arrange for any contact with the ESB, the body in whose authority and competence it lay to award the contracts, they were not required to go to tender on the basis of taking account of the Belfast option. Had the matter been pursued in the normal departmental and inter-departmental manner, it probably would have been possible to arrange that the ESB go to tender on two alternative bases, with and without the Belfast option, and the matter could have been pursued in July-August 1982 on the basis of firm quotations over which tendering firms would have had to stand. The lack of contact with the ESB continued for a lengthy period, with the ESB apparently being brought directly into the matter only on 30 July, although they might possibly have inferred from inquiries in mid-July, three-and-a-half months after the meeting between the Taoiseach and the Belfast unions, that some follow-up to Deputy Haughey's meeting was afoot. There was a failure to pursue the matter in April, May and June 1980 too.

This is the background against which the matter had to be considered following my Government's assumption of office. With a view to seeing whether the position as it then stood could be retrieved, the Minister for Industry and Energy gave the matter detailed attention and there were further contacts from and with various interested parties, including the responsible British Minister and the new managing director of Harland and Wolff. I regret that ultimately the view had to be taken, foreshadowed by my predecessor's letter, that even following these contacts, the potential financial penalties at that stage — in view of the way the matter had been handled in placing a contract on the basis of a ship order in Belfast— appeared too high.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : It is quite clear that the Taoiseach is, in this instance, resorting to a tactic which is now standard with him, that is to try to obscure all important issues and spread confusion by misrepresenting the situation. Would the Taoiseach not agree that every effort was made by my Government to bring this matter to a successful conclusion and, further, that if he puts all the papers before the House they will disclose that the ESB were prevented by my Government from sabotaging this project as long as we were in office, and that they succeeded immediately we left office in going ahead and placing an order for this ship in Japan at an enormous cost to our Exchequer without any benefit whatsoever? Whatever gloss the Taoiseach may endeavour to put on it he will find when the time comes that as far as the hardheaded work force in Harland and Wolff are concerned, they do trust the Fianna Fáil Government more on this issue than his pathetic attempts in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I cannot agree that every effort was made by my predecessor's Government. The simple fact is that no effort was made between 5 April 1982 and mid-July to take any action in the matter, vis-à-vis the ESB.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : The Taoiseach is beginning to lie——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : Will the Deputy withdraw the word “lie”?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : I withdraw the word “lie”, but that is all I withdraw.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I reiterate that lack of contact with the ESB continued well into July. The former Taoiseach's letter, as I read it to the House, is clearly a gentle let down. Because the thing had been muffed, we tried to retrieve it, but the damage had been done and it was too late.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: : Fabrication. Shame on you.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Policy on Northern Ireland .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach which member of the Government and which Government Department now has responsibility for policy on Northern Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : In accordance with the position over the years, policy on Northern Ireland is primarily the responsibility of the Taoiseach. In so far as policy affects relations with the British Government it is also, of course, the concern of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : If the Taoiseach can answer any question these days in simple and direct terms, will he answer my question about who, what member of the Government, is directly and immediately responsible for Northern policy, and what Department has responsibility for administering that policy?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : As I have said, in accordance with the position over the years policy on Northern Ireland is primarily the responsibility of the Taoiseach. The Department of Foreign Affairs obviously have concern with Northern Ireland matters because these matters relate to our relations with another Government. Moreover, the Deputy will be aware that the Department discharge operational functions in relation to Northern Ireland matters, such as, for example, contacts in Northern Ireland, publicising the Government's policy on Northern Ireland abroad, presenting policies to other Governments, etc. As there is such close interaction between policy on Northern Ireland and Irish-British relations, naturally over the years under successive Governments the closest co-operation between the Taoiseach and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and their Departments has been maintained. That position continues, but responsibility for Northern Ireland policy remains with the Taoiseach as it has for as long as I can remember.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : Will the Taoiseach acknowledge that all the staff dealing with Northern Ireland policy are now in the Department of Foreign Affairs and that meetings in connection with Northern Ireland are held in the Department of Foreign Affairs and presided over by the Minister for Foreign Affairs? Does this not indicate quite clearly that Northern Ireland affairs now are clearly and directly the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs? Furthermore, does this not indicate clearly that a number of people in his party and in the Government are not prepared to trust him with the administration of foreign affairs?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : The position is that the responsibility rests with the Taoiseach. As I pointed out, the operational aspects have always been undertaken by the Department of Foreign Affairs. It is true that in the past, under the past administration, a non-civil servant in the Taoiseach's Department played a certain role in these matters which I personally would not regard as constructive. That is obviously a matter of opinion, though that view was held. However, the position has been, apart from that, that the operational aspects——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : Did the Taoiseach refer to a “known civil servant”?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I specifically said “non-civil servant”. The operational aspects always have been undertaken by the Department of Foreign Affairs, as I am well aware from my experience as Minister of the contacts undertaken by that Department. There has been clear functional delineation between the Taoiseach's responsibility and the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Of course the closest co-operation is maintained between the Taoiseach's Department and the Minister for Foreign Affairs upon which the effective operation of Northern Ireland policy depends.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Local Authority Membership .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether any members of the Government continue to be members of local authorities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Further to my reply of 1 March last to the Deputy's previous question on this subject I wish to state that the Tánaiste and Minister for the Environment, Deputy Dick Spring, has now resigned from membership of Tralee Urban District Council. He intends to resign from Kerry County Council at an early date.

The Ministers for Labour and Justice have not yet resigned from the local authorities of which they are members but as I have already indicated it is their intention to do so in accordance with the practice normally followed by Governments in recent years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : Is the Taoiseach aware that he informed the House here on the last occasion when this question was asked that it was the intention of the Minister for the Environment to resign from Kerry County Council, the Minister for Labour to resign from Wicklow County Council and the Minister for Justice to resign from Limerick County Council? Will the Taoiseach say why the explanation he gave to the House on the earlier date was not correct because it has not been implemented?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I said it is their intention to resign. I did not give any date or deadline. Precedents have been set by Fianna Fáil Ministers to stay on as local authority members for much longer than these three Ministers, as I pointed out on the last occasion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : In view of the unsatisfactory and slightly dishonest nature of the reply, I ask the Taoiseach whether he agrees that there is a serious conflict of interests in the Minister for the Environment remaining on as a member of a local authority——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : There certainly is.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : I do not think that it is in accordance with the dignity of the House to attribute dishonesty. That is the second or third time it has happened today, and that is why I raise the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : If the rules of the House require me to withdraw the term, I will do so.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : There are precedents for Ministers in previous Fianna Fáil Governments remaining on as members for much longer periods.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : Does the Taoiseach not consider that there must be a conflict of interests in the Minister for the Environment continuing on as a member of a local authority——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: : Of course there is.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : ——for which he has been charged by this House with responsibility? He is responsible for the funding of that local authority. What kind of standards is the Taoiseach seeking to implement? Has the Minister for the Environment refused to resign or to act on the Taoiseach's request that he resign from Kerry County Council?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Arrangements were made that the members of the Government in due course would resign and well within the time precedent set by Fianna Fáil Ministers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : Has the Taoiseach requested the Minister for the Environment to resign from Kerry County Council?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : No. I have indicated that it has been the practice for Ministers to resign from local authorities, and I have indicated to the members of the Government the time-scale within which previous Fianna Fáil Ministers carried out that operation. I anticipate that the Ministers will resign from local authorities within the time scale precedents set by Fianna Fáil Ministers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: : Will the Taoiseach answer a specific question? Did the Taoiseach request the Minister for the Environment, the Minister for Labour and the Minister for Justice to resign from membership of local authorities?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I indicated that the practice has been for members to resign in a certain period, that I would expect them to do so, and I indicated the time scale set in precedents by Fianna Fáil as being the outer limit for that action.

MainHeading.RHead: Oireachtas Committee on Protection of Marriage
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Oireachtas Committee on Protection of Marriage .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach when it is planned to establish the Oireachtas committee on the problems of the protection of marriage under modern conditions and of marriage break-down, which he promised in the Dáil on 26 January; the consultations he has had or plans to have with the Opposition parties regarding the composition and terms of reference of the committee; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : The Government have been awaiting a response from the main Opposition party to proposals for this and other committees. We are very anxious to set up this committee. I would be happy to have the views of Deputy Mac Giolla on this matter.

MainHeading.P: As soon as consultation are completed it is my intention to proceed immediately with the establishment of the committee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: : The answer was very glibly given. I understand from it that a decision has not been made. Does the Taoiseach recall that in his letter to me of 17 February he stated that the proposal for the composition of this and other committees was almost ready? He also stated that this committee would be asked to report by the end of 1983. What has held up the setting up of this committee?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Consultations with the principal Opposition party.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : I take it the Taoiseach is saying that he is awaiting a response from this party.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Informal consultations have been taking place for some time past. I learned late this morning that the Deputy wishes these consultations of an informal character to be transferred into a formal letter to him setting out what has been under discussion, and I am proceeding to do that immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : I want to ask the Taoiseach does he not think the answer he gave to Deputy Mac Giolla constitutes a misleading of the House, again?

Speaker.hpid: Deputies Deputies
Speaker.P: : Hear, hear.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I do not. We have been awaiting a response from the main Opposition party.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : Will the Taoiseach confirm that, as yet, I as leader of my party and no member of my party have received any request from the Government for the formation of this committee or any positive proposal in regard to it? I hope Deputy Mac Giolla is aware of that situation.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I have to confirm the contrary. Consultations have been in progress for a period of quite a number of weeks. It was with some surprise that I learned this morning that these consultations now require to be translated into a letter to the Leader of the Opposition. I am more than willing to do so. I regret, however, that the Opposition have taken so long to respond in this regard because it is a matter of urgency to get the committee established.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : How dare you?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : The Deputy should address the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : I am sorry a Cheann Comhairle, but some things push me beyond the bounds of reasonably courteous behaviour in this House. Is the Taoiseach endeavouring to suggest that the passing of some incomplete documents by a Minister of that Government to our Chief Whip constitutes consultation about the setting up of an important all-party committee of this House?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I am not aware that the Deputy finds the documents incomplete. If that is the case, this is the first notification we have had of it since the consultations began some six weeks ago.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : Deputy Mac Giolla with a last supplementary question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: : Is it still the Taoiseach's intention that the committee will report by the end of 1983?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Yes. I propose to proceed to establish the committee in the near future. I must, of course, write to the Leader of the Opposition as he now requests me to do so. I will expect to get a reply back from him shortly. One way or the other the committee will be established within the next couple of weeks. If it is to complete its work within that type of deadline—and I aim to have its report by the end of the year — the committee would need to be established fairly soon.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : We must pass on to the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: : There is no need for ultra protection.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : The Deputy will withdraw that remark.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: : I withdraw it, if you are super-sensitive about it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : Did I hear the Taoiseach correctly? Did he state again to Deputy Mac Giolla that the committee will be established?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: : Is the Taoiseach presuming our agreement to participate in the committee?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: : I made it clear — as it was made clear many months ago in our programme for Government — that it is our intention on this occasion, having consulted the Opposition and having given them an opportunity, which they have had at some length, to consider the matter, to proceed to establish the committee. The process in a previous Dáil by which its establishment was frustrated by prolonged failure to respond on the matter will not be allowed to happen in this Dáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: : To whom did the Taoiseach make that clear?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Clogherhead (Louth) Fishery Development .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if it is proposed to buy the fishmeal jetty and premises at Mornington, County Meath, for the use of Clogherhead fishermen, County Louth.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: : My Department have no proposal for the purchase of the fishmeal jetty and premises at Mornington, County Meath. However, in view of the fact that the berthage facilities at present being enjoyed by the fishermen at the jetty may not continue to be available in the future my Department are considering the feasibility of providing alternative berthage in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : Is the Minister aware that there are 29 boats in Clogherhead, that the dock there caters for only 15 boats and that the other 14 boats must go elsewhere to get moorings? Is he further aware that some of these boats are moored at Mornington? In the circumstances, can he state what plans he has for the boats which will no longer be able to use the jetty at Mornington if his Department do not buy the jetty?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The company which owns the jetty is in liquidation. My Department have no plans to purchase any of the assets of that company. Because the jetty and the plant are complementary one cannot be separated from the other. There is a possibility of providing a jetty about 400 yards downstream from the fishmeal premises for the sole use of the fishermen. That is being considered as a temporary measure pending the improvement of the facilities at Clogherhead.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : If the fishermen find the jetty suitable, and had to find it suitable for quite a considerable period, can the Minister state why his Department are now refusing to buy the jetty and the premises?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : It is a matter for the Department to decide whether public money should be spent on the purchase of assets of that nature. In this case it was decided that this asset should not be purchased by the State.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : If the jetty were to be sold in the near future, what alternative arrangements would the Minister have for the boats moored there at present?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : We have been in touch with the liquidator who up to now has given the fishermen facilities for berthing there. In the event of the jetty being purchased we have suggested that the new purchaser might provide the same facilities as have been provided up to now for the local fishermen. In the event of that not being possible — and the Deputy will appreciate that the liquidator cannot insist on such conditions of sale — the Department will look at the possibility of providing temporary facilities about 400 yards downstream until such time as Clogherhead is available to them for berthing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister state what arrangements are being made in respect of temporary facilities at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : We are awaiting the outcome of the sale.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when the development of Clogherhead pier, County Louth, will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : It is proposed to have extensive rehabilitation work carried out on the pier at Clogherhead as soon as possible. However, because of insufficient information on the foundations of the existing structure, the nature of the surrounding sea bed and the effects of wave action, a hydraulic model investigation of the harbour had to be undertaken.

This investigation is now completed and my Department expect to have the findings, together with an engineering report from the Office of Public Works, at an early date. Pending receipt of this report I am not in a position to say when the work will be carried out.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister state when he can make a decision with regard to this survey?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The hydraulic model investigation has been completed. This has been done under the auspices of University College, Cork. From inquiries made I understand the final report will be with the Department within a month or two.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister reply to my question? Will he say when he expects to be able to give the go-ahead to the reconstruction works at Clogherhead?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The Deputy will appreciate that first I shall have to look at the contents of the report of the hydraulic investigation survey. Secondly, I wish to point out that commencement of work will depend on the availability of funds for such work.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : Even if the results of the survey were to hand, were fully considered and accepted, in view of the cut-backs initiated by the Government will it be the position that money will not be available to go ahead with the work?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I have not said that. It is something that will be discussed in the context of the 1984 Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: : There is very little hope for Clogherhead in view of the answers given by the Minister.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Helvic Head (Waterford) Improvement Works .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Fahey Mr. J. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if improvement works will be carried out to the Helvic Head, County Waterford; and, if so, when work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I presume the question relates to the harbour at Helvick Head, County Waterford. I am awaiting an engineering report on this harbour from the Office of Public Works and until this report is received and examined I cannot state what improvements, if any, will be carried out with the aid of a State grant or when the work will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Valentia Harbour (Kerry) Development .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has any plans to develop Valentia Harbour, County Kerry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : In recent years substantial harbour improvement works have been carried out at Knightstown and Portmagee and a major scheme is nearing completion at Cahirciveen.

A submission on the further development of Valentia Harbour which has been received from the Kerry County Development Team is, in the fisheries context, being examined at present in my Department. Until this examination is completed it is not possible to say what further fisheries development works, if any, would be warranted at Valentia Harbour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister arrange for a meeting with interested parties in south-west Kerry in connection with the proposals at present in his Department?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : That can be done. I see no reason for not being able to discuss these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: : Is the Minister aware of the urgent necessity to develop this harbour from the point of view of the social and economic development of the area and also from the point of view of the fishing industry in general?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I should like to point out to the Deputy that as far back as 1959 a survey was carried out on the development of this harbour. At that time the estimated cost was said to be in the region of £348,000. The South Kerry Survey Team considered that, because of the excessive cost and in the expectation of getting developments under way elsewhere, less expensive works should be undertaken elsewhere, which have been done at Cahirciveen, Knightstown and Portmagee during the years. This was the recommendation of the survey team. Work has taken place in the area but if the Deputy wishes that a meeting be arranged I will gladly accede to that request.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: : I am very happy with the Minister's agreement to meet those people interested in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Inshore and Coastal Fisheries .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he proposes to introduce legislation for the control and management of the inshore and coastal fisheries in line with the Irish Federation of Sea Anglers document entitled Proposals for the future development of Sea Angling in Ireland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will implement as a matter of urgency the necessary legislation for the control and management of the inland and coastal fisheries in line with the Irish Federation of Sea Anglers document entitled Proposals for the further Development of Sea Angling in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I propose to take Questions Nos. 12 and 13 together.

My Department have for some time been considering the introduction of a zoning arrangement in respect of our inshore waters but it has not been possible so far to find a sufficient degree of agreement for an arrangement whereby each category of fishermen would enjoy an equitable share of access to available resources of fish.
In the circumstances I am not prepared, at this juncture, to consider the introduction of legislation on the lines proposed which would be very difficult to enforce.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister ensure that when his Department are deciding on arrangements regarding the various zones they will consult with fishermen throughout the country?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : That has been part of the problem. I could lay down certain regulations on the basis of zoning of areas and so on, but it would be foolish to do so without consultation because of the difficulty in implementing regulations. The problem is that consultations have taken place before this but we have not got agreement between the different categories of fishermen operating in our waters. It is on these consultations and the seeking of arrangements that the whole thing has broken down.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: : Has the Minister any plans to meet the federation to discuss these issues and other matters of relevance? Has he met the federation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I have met any group representing fishermen who have asked to meet me or my Minister of State. We have met such groups without any preconditions and without any difficulty. If the Federation of Sea Anglers wish to meet either of us, they are very welcome to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: : The Minister has said that talks have broken down with the fishermen in relation to zoning. Does he intend commencing further talks?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I should like to see agreement and if I thought there was any possibility of getting that agreement I should be very glad to bring the various parties together and initiate talks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: : Will the Minister accept——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : We cannot debate this matter at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: : This is in the national interest. Will the Minister extend an invitation to various organisations to meet with him or with his Minister of State and to commence further talks?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : There is a suggestion, with which I agree, that the sectoral consultative committee for the fishing industry would handle this matter for the moment. They represent the various parties and it might be better if they initiated talks and see how they get along.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - County Wexford Fishing Trawler Loss .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will investigate and correct an error made by Bord Iascaigh Mhara in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Wexford in relation to the loss of a fishing trawler which was in collision with a passenger carrier en route from France; whether the board required payment of interest on the loan between the date of the loss of the trawler and the date of the settlement of the insurance claim; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I have been informed by An Bord Iascaigh Mhara that no error was made by them in relation to the calculation of interest due on foot of a loan provided in respect of a fishing vessel which was lost on 1 August 1982, off the Wexford coast. The loan agreement provided that interest be charged on the loan until such time as the loan had been repaid and as repayment was made to the board on 8 October 1982, interest totalling IR£1,470.32 was correctly charged in respect of the period 1 August to 30 September 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: : Is it possible that the Minister agrees that interest should be charged on a trawler that could not be in use after an accident? I ask him to reconsider the situation with a view to correcting what I and, I think, all Members of this House would consider to be an error. When a trawler is not in use the person concerned should not be asked to pay interest on a loan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The problem is not as simple as that. There is a question of insurance involved. While I appreciate the obvious practical difficulty, on foot of agreements entered into and the possibility of a loss with regard to an insurance claim, it would be difficult to interfere in this situation without upsetting an agreement and thus causing a more serious loss to the boat owner.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: : As the Minister agrees with the sentiment of my question, would he not go back to Bord Iascaigh Mhara who claim to help Irish fishermen? Here is an obvious case where help could be offered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I will go back to Bord Iascaigh Mhara, but they are a party to a solemn, legally binding agreement. If one party breaks that agreement, problems could arise in connection with an insurance claim in the matter. I can put this question to Bord Iascaigh Mhara and see how far they can go on these lines. I accept the tenor of the Deputy's remarks.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - County Donegal Pier Development .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when it is proposed to continue work on the development of Portmore Pier, Malin Head, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : In 1981 an electrically operated crane and two recessed ladders were provided at Portmore at a cost of £40,000 towards which my Department contributed a grant of £30,000.

Full consideration has also been given to a development scheme sought by the local fishermen, comprising the extension of the pier and the raising of the stormwall by six feet. The substantial expenditure involved in extending the pier could not be justified having regard to the limited amount of fishing from this landing place. As to the second request, the Department have been advised by the Office of Public Works that the raising of the stormwall by six feet would not prevent heavy seas from breaking over the pier. A proposal by the fishermen to fill in the set of steps between the two new ladders is at present being examined in my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : Would the Minister not agree that Portmore is the most northerly point in this country, facing the open Atlantic? While the fishermen appreciated the installation of a crane there which was of great benefit to them, in winter seas lash over the pier and damage boats there. Would the Minister reconsider the decision? It is the opinion of the fishermen that if the sea wall were raised, it would be of benefit and provide protection for them and their boats.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : As I have said, the major problem here is that the engineering report states that the provision of extra height would not solve the problem and expenditure of a very substantial sum of money would not be justified on the basis that the landings at this pier are not sufficient to justify great expenditure. The proposal to fill the steps between the two ladders is being examined at present by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Dunmore Coast (Waterford) Fishing .

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the reason trawlers are being allowed to fish inside the six mile limit off the Dunmore coast area of County Waterford with resulting severe damage to the gear of the inshore fishermen of Passage East and Dunmore East.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : There is no prohibition on trawling by Irish boats of under 90 feet in length in the area within six miles seaward of baselines in the area mentioned. Boats of 90 feet or over may not, however, fish within three miles from baselines. It is considered that a ban on trawling within six miles from baselines would not be justified.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: : I referred specifically to beam trawlers. Perhaps the Minister might give me a reply on that point?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : Beam trawling for sole and plaice by boats of 70 gross registered tonnes or 300 brake horsepower inside 12 miles from baseline is banned under an EEC regulation in connection with the CFP. The question, as I understand it, relates to Irish boats only, most of which are below the limits mentioned — in fact, the bulk of them are.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: : My question referred to a lower limit with regard to beam trawling. I asked this specific question because there are Irish inshore boats based in an adjoining county which are causing extreme damage to the boats in Passage East and Dunmore. Is the Minister aware that a blind eye is being turned to these boats coming in?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : May I point out that fishing licences granted to Irish boats of 90 feet and upwards prohibit them from such fishing? Also, the Naval Service have been active in that area recently and have not disclosed any illegal activities there.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : A final supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: : My information is that a blind eye is being turned to these boats. They are fishing out of Kilmore Quay into the adjoining county. Would the Junior Minister be able to help, as this is in his constituency?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I assure the Deputy and the House that a blind eye is not being turned to illegal fishing operations. I would not condone such a practice. I am also quite sure that the Naval Service would not turn a blind eye in those circumstances, have not done so, and are not doing so.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: : The Minister may convince me but I would like him to be able to convice the fishermen of the south-east.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Moville Pier (Donegal) Works .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make a statement on Moville Pier, County Donegal, with particular reference to the cause of the collapse of the new part of the pier.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : Moville Pier is vested in the Harbour Commissioners for the port of Derry. Work on the present structure was completed in 1976 as part of an improvement scheme carried out for the benefit of local fishermen. The scheme was financed by a grant from my Department and a contribution from the commissioners. Following completion of the work the commissioners assumed responsibility for future maintenance of the pier.

During a storm in 1980 a portion of the outer end of the pier collapsed. Following investigations by engineers of the Office of Public Works and my Department it emerged that substantial dredging alongside the pier was carried out by the harbour commissioners during the summer of 1979 in order to facilitate the operation of a ferry service between Oban in Scotland and Moville. The engineers of the Office of Public Works and my Department are in agreement that the dredging led to the collapse of the pier.
In the light of the foregoing, this Department consider that the repair of the pier is a matter for the harbour commissioners and are in negotiation with them in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : How much of a grant was given for the original repair?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The harbour improvement scheme to which the Deputy refers cost £95,000, of which my Department contributed £80,000, the balance being contributed by the harbour commissioners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : In view of this Government's large commitment with regard to this work, is the Minister satisfied that the works carried out were of a satisfactory nature? Has he obtained an engineer's report certifying that these works were of the requisite quality?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : Consultations have taken place between the Commissioners, my Department and the Office of Public Works. The Department's case was put on foot of the original agreement which laid responsibility for maintenance on the shoulders of the harbour commissioners. The chief executive of the commissioners was to report to a committee of his harbour commissioners in November 1982 and was to advise the Department of the commissioners' views on this matter. The harbour commissioners have not communicated with my Department since that meeting.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : Question No. 18.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: : When formulating any plan for the extension of Moville pier will the Minister take into consideration the large quantities of mackerel being landed there by the super trawlers while there are berthing facilities for two boats only?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I appreciate the problem mentioned by the Deputy. The fact is that the particular development was agreed at the time between my Department and the commissioners.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Inch Lough (Donegal) Wild Life Development .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has any proposals for the development and management of the Inch Lough wild life area, County Donegal; and, if so, if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : There are no immediate proposals in relation to this privately-owned property but the situation is being kept under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : I do not accept that this is a privately owned lake——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : A question, please, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : Would the Minister agree that there is a case here for a conservation order in respect of the wild life at this lake in view of the fact that it was designated as one of the principal wetlands of Europe when the 1976-77 survey was undertaken? In view of that would the Minister not consider that there is a case here for a conservation order being put on it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I might point out that the Deputy is labouring under a misapprehension. My Department have now ascertained beyond any doubt that the property referred to is privately owned. For that reason any attempt to stop proposed development there, for example, drainage, would entail negotiations to purchase or some kind of management agreement with the owners which would involve heavy compensation payment. Therefore, the private ownership aspect is causing certain problems.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : I might point out to the Minister that this is a public lake and that public fishing takes place there. Also, from my correspondence with his Department, it would appear that the answer he has now given the House does not conform with the reply I received.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : We are getting into argument now and that is not in order at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : Might I ask the Minister how many nature reserve orders have been made under the Wildlife Act in the Republic?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : That would seem to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I have not got that information. However, I can tell the Deputy that there are six such areas in the Deputy's county. I might tell him also that we have been assured by the private owners that they will consult with us before they undertake any proposed development and that they will let us know what they have in mind. At this time they tell us that, from a financial viability point of view, they are not proceeding with the development planned at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : I might point out——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : We must move on. I have given the Deputy very considerable latitude on this question. I have called the next question but because it is Deputy Conaghan I will——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: : In view of the lack of any policy in relation to conservation under the Wildlife Act is the Minister aware that in the Six Counties — which comprise a fifth only of the area of the country — there are over 60 nature reserves, 44 areas of scientific interest and many important areas owned by the National Trust? In view of the lack of any conservation development in relation to wild life would the Minister seriously consider this important wild life area which was designated by the European Commission as an important wetland? Would the Minister take due consideration of the importance of this area in relation to conservation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I fully accept the importance of wild life conservation but I would point out to the Deputy that the allegation that we have no policy is totally erroneous. Indeed there is a major piece of legislation on our Statute Book put through this House by the present Ceann Comhairle.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - County Limerick Forestry Employment Application .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the present position in regard to an application by a person (details supplied) for employment in his Department as a labourer in the forestry at Ardpatrick, Kilfinnan, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : There are no vacancies in this area at present. However, following his application for employment the person in question has been interviewed by the local forester-in-charge and will be considered in the context of any future vacancies that may arise.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Private Forestry Land Purchase .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make a statement on the purchase of land for private forestry in congested districts where small farmers need the land.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : While I am most anxious to stimulate and encourage private forestry throughout the country — especially in the western region for which very generous planting grants are now available — I am convinced that, as in the case of the State afforestation programme, the overall national interest is best served by restricting private forestry to lands which are not suitable or required for agricultural purposes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: : Would the Minister agree that previously land which was suitable for farming purposes was planted? Is it not time that his Department carried out a survey of the land remaining to ensure that the worst type of land is planted because at present there is no policy, or no selective method used to determine what areas are planted?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The scheme operated by my Department concerns marginal lands which are not suitable for agricultural purposes. We are restricted, in a very practical way, in that the price we are allowed pay for land is subject to scrutiny elsewhere and that determines very quickly what kind of land we can purchase for the purpose of afforestation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: : Would the Minister not agree that a survey should be carried out to identify meadowland not suitable for farming which would be suitable for afforestation, especially now that there are substantial grants forthcoming from the EEC for private afforestation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : The information in relation to the kind of land available is already available, I am sure, in the Agricultural Institute.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: : Can the Minister give us some details of the recent statements of the Minister of State in relation to leasing arrangements, some novel ideas he was putting forward in relation to leasing arrangements?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : That seems to be a very different question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: : Is the Minister aware of the statements by the Minister of State?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I am well aware.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the amount of mature timber exported in a raw state in each year from 1977 to 1982, inclusive.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Kiln Drying Timber Facilities .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the facilities available for kiln drying timber in the State; where they are located; and the capacity of each.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : Records containing the precise information requested are not compiled by my Department. However, following inquiries made in the industry and elsewhere, I understand that in all 19 firms have kiln drying facilities, the aggregate capacity of which is in the region of 1,440 cubic metres. Further details are contained in a tabular statement which I propose to circulate with the Official Report.
Following is the statement:

row.entry: Cavan, Galway, Leitrim, Longford, Meath, Offaly, Sligo, Wicklow

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: : Does the Minister accept that this is totally inadequate for the needs of the timber industry for the purpose of supplying the construction industry? Has he any plans for the establishment of kiln drying facilities to ensure that the timber which is available can be dried to a suitable standard for the construction industry?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I should point out to the Deputy that all timber sawn in Irish mills is not dried in this manner, that proportion only which is necessary to meet specifications as to moisture content for housebuilding, specialised fencing and so on is subjected to kiln drying. It constitutes an additional cost factor which generally is avoided unless absolutely necessary. Therefore, I should point out that it would be wrong of us to take on this extra cost and, by so doing, become less competitive.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: : Does the Minister accept that the capacity available is totally inadequate for supplying the timber required?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : I am not convinced that that is so.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions . Oral Answers . - Forestry Financial Aid .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the assistance available by way of grants, loans or allocation of lands to encourage landowners to engage in forestry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: : My Department operate two grant schemes aimed at encouraging private forestry. One of these schemes is subvented by the EEC as part of the western package, and applies for practical purposes to the western region; the other relates to the rest of the country. A free technical advisory service is a feature of both schemes. I have asked that the relevant brochures containing the various grant schemes be sent to the Deputy forthwith.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: : The remaining questions will appear on tomorrow's Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
